body:
The application has no concept of the PC being suspended.
There is no "resuming", the application just runs exactly as it did before and just tries to handle errors caused by the sleep (which usually results in broken network connections). 
I am sure that the node connections are retried within the specified retry period
The announcement seems to be retried once half an hour too, but this is not exactly required if you are resuming the application, as the application already knows where the nodes are, so the fact that it's offline is not that important.

Is there no way to check with the OS for suspension?

Otherwise, it might be possible to keep an internal time value "last active", which is checked every few seconds. If the last value differs too much, the OS was probably suspended.

That's probably your best bet.

In that case, it probably makes sense for Syncthing just to restart.

Yeah, we could notice that we've been paused longer than expected. If we go down that route, there's a lot of stuff we need to recheck, since _everything_ might have changed under our feet.
- Our IP numbers have probably changed, so discovery needs to be restarted.
- UPnP needs to be restarted to get a new external port.
- Connections to retry, as above.
- Contents on disk might have changed a lot (we don't know why we were paused, might have been that the user sent a SIGSTOP).

It's almost cleaner to just restart, apart from that being a surprising thing for a program to do on it's own...

> The application has no concept of the PC being suspended.

If your clock jumps forward nine hundred seconds...

Ah @calmh was there first.
Edit: and everyone else. oops.

Initially had sleep for a minute, allow up to 30 seconds drift. 

Worked like a charm on Windows, though managed to time it quite well two times in a row on Linux for it not to work.

But then having 1 minute sleep with 1 second drift can also give bad results...

Fixes #565

issue.title: WebUI is sometimes blank

repository.name: SyncTrayzor
repository.description: Windows tray utility / filesystem watcher / launcher for Syncthing

issue.body:
Occasionally (after a long syncthrayzor's uptime period), opening main UI shows blank white page.
Waiting a long period does nothing, "Menu->Syncthing->Refresh browser" does nothing, "Menu->Syncthing->Restart syncthing" has no effect.

The only way to restore UI functionality is to close it entirely (menu->file->exit) and relaunch.
So it seems like the wrapper fails to communicate with the ST itself properly.

In the background the actual syncthing seem to be working, syncing occurs properly.

SyncTrayzor log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/0b8c1f43babccbdcbea2d03eaa7c3243
Syncthing log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/d4628810f8393f7c476a4f12c5caca36

Note:
I'm not entirely sure if it's synctrayzor's fault, I have never encountered it with standalone syncthing, but then again I access standalone installation much less often then the synctrayzor's ones...

Environment: SyncTrayzor v.1.1.11, Syncthing v.0.13.10, OS: Win10 x64

issue.title: WebGUI is sometimes inaccessible

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age

issue.body:
Occasionally after a prolonged uptime period, UI may become inaccessible.

ST log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/d4628810f8393f7c476a4f12c5caca36
`http://localhost:8385/debug/pprof/goroutine?debug=2` contents for whatever worth: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/f31e8f71380cd6c9bc090f0d2c0b7a32

As far as UI goes, everything seems dead, though the syncing is up and running, files do fly around. 

The thing is that a while ago, following the discussion on [restartOnWakeup setting](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/question-about-restartonwakeup-setting/2222/7), I disabled it.
And this issue I'm having is appearing after wake-from-sleep. So, maybe there's a connection. 
(the original issue regarding restartOnWakeup: syncthing/syncthing#565)

Originally I suspected that it was SyncTrayzor's fault. 
The issue has been discussed here: https://github.com/canton7/SyncTrayzor/issues/292 .

Syncthing Version: v0.13.10
OS Version: Windows 10 x64
